summary: This is a Palm Beach Post editorial from November 16, 2007, criticizing the potential plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein. It argues that a plea to a single felony count of solicitation of prostitution, which would not recognize the underage status of the victims, would be an injustice. The editorial details the police investigation, the grand jury indictment, and Epstein's high-powered legal team, expressing concern that wealth can influence the criminal justice system.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The Manhattan money manager and part-time Palm Beach resident indicted by a grand jury for solicitation of prostitution, with police alleging he paid underage girls for 'massage' sessions.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: The Palm Beach County State Attorney who, after an 11-month police investigation, sent the Epstein case to a grand jury instead of filing charges himself after defense attorneys presented information about the alleged victims' MySpace pages.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: A West Palm Beach defense attorney on Jeffrey Epstein's legal team who stated the case would end without a trial within two months.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: A Harvard Law School professor and member of Jeffrey Epstein's legal team, noted for his work on the O.J. Simpson murder case.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: A member of Jeffrey Epstein's legal team, formerly known for pursuing President Bill Clinton over lies about sex with a young woman.

persons.name: Jose Lambiet
persons.context: A reporter for The Palm Beach Post who wrote an article citing an unnamed source close to Epstein about the status of the federal investigation and a potential plea deal.

persons.name: Michael Edmondson
persons.context: The spokesman for the State Attorney's office who would not confirm a plea deal but noted the state attorney was not precluded from filing additional charges.

connections.description: Goldberger is identified as a West Palm Beach defense attorney on Epstein's legal team.
Dershowitz, a Harvard Law professor, is identified as a member of Epstein's legal team.
Starr is identified as a member of Epstein's legal team.
Krischer, as State Attorney, was the prosecutor who handled the initial investigation before sending the case to a grand jury.
Goldberger provided a statement to reporter Jose Lambiet about the case ending without a trial.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein on one felony count of solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Report on Plea Deal
events.description: Reporter Jose Lambiet, citing an unnamed source close to Epstein, wrote that the federal investigation was over and Epstein was expected to serve up to 18 months and be labeled a sex offender.

events.title: Editorial Publication
events.description: The Palm Beach Post published this editorial criticizing the potential plea deal and the handling of the Epstein case.

keyFacts: Police alleged Jeffrey Epstein paid underage girls, one as young as 14, for 'massage' sessions at his Palm Beach home.
After an 11-month police investigation, State Attorney Barry Krischer sent the case to a grand jury instead of filing charges directly, a move the editorial criticizes.
Epstein's high-powered legal team included Jack Goldberger, Alan Dershowitz, and Kenneth Starr.

A reported plea deal would involve Epstein pleading guilty to a charge carrying up to 18 months in prison and a sex offender label, unlike the original grand jury charge which carried a maximum five-year term.
The editorial argues the case exemplifies how wealth can influence the criminal justice system, allowing predators to 'buy their way out' of appropriate punishment.
